speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the feeding difficulties you're experiencing? Are you having trouble with latching, or is it more of a problem with the amount of food you're willing to eat?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, it's not that I'm not latching, mom is doing everything right. It's just... I don't feel like eating, and even when I do, I get really uncomfortable and start crying. And it's not like I'm not gaining weight, like mom says, but I just don't feel hungry all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the abdominal distension, is it a constant feeling or does it come and go, and have you noticed any other symptoms like vomiting or diarrhea?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, doc, it's more like a feeling than a constant, but it's been getting worse lately. It's like my tummy's getting a bit... tight, and it's really uncomfortable when mom holds me or puts me down. I don't know, it's just a funny feeling, but it makes me cry when it happens."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the feeding difficulties? For example, are there any particular foods that you don't like or seem to tolerate better than others?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really like the feeling of being full, I guess. Whenever mom tries to feed me, I'll eat a little bit, but then I just stop. And when I'm not eating, it's like... I just don't feel like doing anything, even playing or sleeping. It's like my body just doesn't want to do anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: So you mentioned feeding difficulties and abdominal distension, I'd like to examine your abdomen to see if I can notice anything unusual. Can you please lift your shirt and let me take a look?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, doc... *lifts shirt* I don't know what to expect, but I just hope it's not something that hurts or makes me cry more."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'm going to take a look at your abdomen now. I notice that it's quite distended, and there are a few palpable masses on either side. Can you tell me more about how long you've been experiencing this? Was it sudden or did it develop over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "Hmm, I don't really know... it just started a few days ago, I think. Mom says it's been getting worse, but I don't really remember when it first started. I just feel really uncomfortable and it makes me cry a lot."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the masses you feel on your abdomen, are they hard or soft, and are they tender to the touch?



Please don't worry, I'm just trying to get a better understanding of what might be going on. Can you show me exactly where these masses are located on your abdomen?



REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound of the abdomen

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Abdominal examination findings: Abdomen is soft but distended, with crying intensifying on palpation especially in the left lower quadrant, suggesting possible intestinal obstruction. No masses palpable.

speaker: Doctor
text:

Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms like coughing, wheezing, or difficulty breathing?



Can you move your arms and legs for me to see if there's any restriction in your movement?

Can you show me the area where the masses are located on your abdomen again, and I'd like to take some more notes on the size and shape of the masses?

speaker: Patient
text:
"Uh, doc, I'm not really sure... I mean, I feel them on either side of my tummy, but I don't know exactly where they are. They just kinda... feel there, I guess. *fidgets slightly*"

"Hmm, okay... *takes deep breaths*... I don't really notice anything different when I breathe in or out. I just feel a little... uncomfortable, like I said. *coughs slightly*"

"No, I don't think so... I don't really feel like I'm having trouble breathing or anything. I just get really upset when I feel the... the feeling in my tummy. *looks down*"

"I can move my arms and legs, doc... *lifts arms and legs slightly*... I don't feel like anything's really restricted, but I'm not really sure what you're looking for. *looks up*"

"Uh, okay... *taps tummy gently*...

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken note of the location of the masses and the tenderness of the area. I'd like to request a test to confirm the presence of any fluid accumulation in the abdomen, so can I request a REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound of the abdomen, please?



Also, I'd like to ask, have you noticed any fever or discomfort in your chest, and can you tell me more about the feeding difficulties you mentioned earlier, such as whether you're having trouble with swallowing or if food is getting stuck in your throat?



And one more thing, I'd like to check for any signs of dehydration by asking, have you been urinating regularly and have you noticed any changes in your urine output?

speaker: Patient
text:
"I don't know, doc... I think they're always a bit tender, but sometimes they feel worse when mom holds me or puts me down. Like, if she's holding me close and I'm sitting on her lap, I might feel a bit more uncomfortable and cry. But if she just holds my arm or something, I don't feel as bad."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed all the test results and examined your abdomen, neck, and throat thoroughly. Based on the ultrasound results, complete blood count, and electrolyte panel, I'm concerned that you may have a condition called intussusception. It appears that there's a possible obstruction in your intestine that's causing the abdominal distension and masses. I'd like to request a REQUEST TEST: X-Ray of the abdomen to confirm the presence of any blockages or abnormalities.
